15513.content:
As you proceeded on the path, you felt the air get hotter. As expected when you approach the volcano. You couldn't imagine why your parents would go to a place like this. They weren't particularly powerful here, and it was crawling with fiery Pokémon. Such Pokémon usually stunk of sulfur and BO. You could already smell the stink of sulfur. You soon crossed from grasslands to stone.

You looked out and saw coal-black stone, lit gently by the glow of pools of lava within craters dotting the landscape. You saw a path heading up to a cavern in the side of the volcano, but first you'd have to pas through the landscape. For the path led up to the mouth of that cave. You both looked at each other, and nodded, fearful yet in understanding. You had to commence. You both marched forth, attempting to puff out your chests.
15513.title: ...to a nearby volcano

1552.content:
“Are you serious?”

You mumbled angrily to yourself as you pad down the dirt paths weaving all through the forest, sniffing at the ground, trying to track the scent of your far-away parents. “They just… left. They just left!” You murmured quietly, feeling ever so slightly pissed off. “In the middle of the night! You have got to be kidding me. I knew they were petty, but this…” Hell no. You’re not letting them get away with this. They weren’t going to get rid of you that easy. You were going to track them down and give them a piece of your mind, at least.

They had made some occasional references to dropping you out of the nest, which you weren’t opposed to, but you certainly didn’t expect that the day you hit what most would consider adulthood, they would up and vanish in the middle of the night without even bothering to say ‘goodbye’. Apparently, without having every taught you any survival skills whatsoever, they expected you to just suddenly start surviving on your own without warning. Or maybe they just didn’t care if you lived or died. Either way, you weren’t going to be thrown away like yesterday’s trash. You were trailing their scent as best you could; your father’s, a zoroark, scent was the strongest, the unwashed buffoon. He was probably the one that came up with this. Your mother, meek as she was, always went with whatever plan your father decided on, which made you both loathe and pity her in equal measures. All in all, your childhood wasn’t the best, being sheltered away from the world and stuck in a tree all day… but that was behind you now.

You were technically independent now, though you had no idea what you were doing. And you’ve always been a bit of runt, so you didn’t know how well you’d stand your ground against hungry wild Pokemon. Still, you had to track them down, no matter the cost, if only just to get an explanation out of them. Your rage overriding your fear of the unknown, you press onwards into the wilderness, not even bothering to check for predators as you focus on tracking your parents’ scent.

That is, until you noticed the sound of something rustling in the bushes. It was subtle, almost silent, but your attuned ears just managed to pick it. You freeze, sniffing the air to see if you could identify your pursuer by scent. Whoever they were, you’ve definitely never met them before. “S-show yourself!” You yelled into the bushes, feigning bravery. Predators would be less likely to attack if you stood your group, you knew that much. Your heart was pounding in your chest as a wild Pokemon slowly emerged from the overgrowth...
1552.title: Absol

choices: ...she leaned down to snap you in her jaws
15521.content:
You didn't believe your eyes at first, but, sure enough, you saw an Aurorus. This large creature bore icy-blue scales, a lighter underbelly, elegant frills on either side of her head, and an undeniable elegance about her. Something about how smooth she looked, in tandem with her coloration, struck you as uniquely beautiful. Still, you had to wonder what she was doing out here. You were positive creatures like her normally resided in cold, snowy areas. You then noticed a thin fog emanating from her body. That wasn't a normal fog though, that was her cold body! She was so cold, she emanated a chill around herself.

Beyond that, as she approached, you began to notice how large she was. You weren't the biggest creature, but you were still almost 4 feet tall. She was easily over twice your height, and even larger than you. Her head looked like it could store a third of your body without swallowing. And beneath that neck, was a stomach about as large as a small hut compared to your relatively smaller body. And, just below those hips, was a rear that could cover you 6 times over. She noticed you, and began approaching.

"Just when I was about to give up on this search," the Auroras said. From her tone of voice, she sounded almost nurturing. Then...
15521.title: An Auroras!

choices: ... small, humble village in the woods.
15522.content:
You realized you were suddenly face-to-face with a Ninetales, who looked just as surprised as you did that you ran into eachother. She was about a foot taller than you, and looked old enough to be your mother. It was obvious she had been surviving in the wilderness for quite a long time; her back was covered in scars from previous battles, and her fur was dirty and ragged, though she did look oddly well-fed. Most notably, she was wearing a long, thick red band as a blindfold of some sort. While she couldn’t see you, she could definitely hear you coming, and tensed up. “W-who are you?” You ask, curiously, a little startled by her sudden appearance from the trees. All of a sudden, she lunged forward, pouncing at you and sending you flying back through the air, pinning you against the ground beneath some thick bushes. “Mph!”

“Keep... quiet...” She whispered harshly, practically burying you between her body, holding you tightly against the ground.

“What the hell? Get off m-” You say, starting to struggle against her.

“Shut up!” She hissed quietly. You were about to fight back, until you heard another sound in the distance; the stomping of some immense Pokemon, kicking up dirt and pushing over trees with its every step. You freeze up, suddenly unwilling to make a single sound as the two of you hid in the bushes, hearing the monumental creature draw closer. Eventually, it pushes the trees aside as it steps into the open field, and you finally get a good look at the ninetale’s pursuer. A huge scolipede loomed over you, bigger than any Pokemon you’ve ever seen in person, her head looming over many of the smaller trees. She was probably about four times your size!

“I heard something over here! Weren’t you known as the most silent Pokemon in this forest? You’ve really lost your touch, haven’t you?” The scolipede cackled, in a booming, deep voice, taunting the hiding ninetales. You don’t even blink as the scolipede walks by, the sounds of her heavy steps ringing in your ears. The ninetales on top of you had gone completely still, like a statue. You were pretty sure she wasn’t even breathing. “You’re getting old, little fox. Can’t hide like you used to. You’ll slip up eventually...” Figuring the ninetales would never stay in one place for too long, the scolipede continued through the wilderness, disappearing back into the overgrowth.

The ninetales stays hidden with you, remaining completely still, able to easily judge the scolipede’s distance with her acute sense of hearing. You find it slightly awkward to be pressed up so close against her for so long, but still, you try to keep quiet. Eventually, she seems certain that the scolipede had left, and sits up. “Hmph,” she says, in a low, frustrated tone as she climbs off you. “Word of advice, kid. Out in the wild, there’s no reason to ever be so damn loud.” Just like that, she pads away, as if nothing had ever happened… leaving you there, confused.

As you stand on wobbly legs, it occurs to you that the ninetales had probably just saved your life. You wished she would stick around to explain, but it seemed she had places to be. You sighed, returning to your task of tracking down your parents… only to realize that their scent led you in exactly the same direction the ninetales was walking. You investigated, only to find a small dirt path winding through the woods. Your parent’s pawprints were still evident in the mud. They’d been through here recently. Seems like you and the ninetales were heading the same way after all.

You walk down the path, trekking behind the ninetales, sniffing the air and keeping an eye out for pawprints, trying to make it obvious you’re not just following her. Unfortunately, you fail. “Why are you following me?” She asks, not even bothering to look over her shoulder at you.

“Uh… w-we’re actually heading in the same direction...”You stuttered.

“... sure,” she replied, her tone unreadable. The two of you walk in silence for a while, with you growing increasingly embarrassed.

“Yeeaah…” You say uncomfortably, staring at the ground. You were still bursting with adrenaline after the brush with the scolipede, and desperately wanted to talk about it with someone. You had never been so close to a hostile predator, after all. Unfortunately, you had no friends, and your parents were nowhere to be found, so this random ninetales was the only Pokemon you could discuss it with. “So, uh, heh, that whole thing was pretty intense, right? What was that all about?”

“Why are you asking?” She asks, still hardly acknowledging your presence.

“Just… m-making conversation,” you say, a little taken back by the question. It seems she wasn’t a big fan of talking, but you were still feeling desperate to save face. “I mean, heh, I haven’t really talked to many Pokemon before. Besides my folks.” You chuckle awkwardly, your face flushed. “Who I’m… sort of looking for. You haven’t happened to see a Zoroark around here, have you?”

“No,” she replied, simply.

“Ah,” you nodded, and the two of you walked silently for a few minutes more. The ninetales was kind of attractive, you noticed, in a rugged, creepy sort of way. It didn’t help that she was so tall you were about eye-level with her shapely ass, which swayed in front of your face as she walked, beneath her gorgeous tails. You tried not to stare. “So… is that a blindfold you’re wearing?” You ask, trying to divert your attention to something else.

“Yes,” she said, giving brief, one-word answers, as if she doesn’t want to spare the energy to even speak with you.

“How do you see?”

“... I don’t,” she replied. It was kind of a dumb question, you suppose, but it was apparently dumb enough for the ninetales to stop in her tracks completely. She turned to face you, and you realize you’ve probably just been pissing her off this entire time. “You’re not very bright, are you?” She growled.

“Uh... I guess not,” you reply, backing away as she loomed over you. “I mean… this is kind of my first day out here, so I don’t really know what I’m doing…”

She stands there for a few moments. You’d almost think she was staring at you, if it wasn’t for the blindfold. Eventually, she sighed, letting her anger and frustration melt away. “Listen, kid. I’ve pissed off some seriously bad Pokemon, so forgive me if I’m a little paranoid,” she said, trying her best to act rational. “But if you’re telling the truth, your parents are probably in the next town, just a few miles up. Once we get there, I want you to buzz off, okay? I don’t want to see you around me again.”

“T-there’s a…?” You had no idea there was a town nearby. Your father told you there was only empty wilderness for miles and miles around here. Then again, he wasn’t a very reliable source. Deciding not to question her further, you nod. “Okay.”

“Alright. You walk in front,” she says, standing there, leaving you to reluctantly walk ahead. You couldn’t hear her, though, so after a while you were afraid she might’ve just ditched you -- but when you eventually glanced over your shoulder, sure enough, she was there. Her footsteps simply didn’t make a sound. Her movements were almost eerily quiet, the ninetales practically gliding along the ground with an almost robotic rhythm. She definitely lived up to her reputation. You tried to pretend she wasn’t even there, opting to just stare at the ground and contemplate the situation.

Eventually, the two of you came upon a...
15522.title: Ninetales

choices: You sleep in the nest with the ninetales
155222.content:
By the time you made it to the next town, it was dusk, and the small village was silhouetted by the beautiful sunset in the background. You stood over the town in awe, inspired by the skilled architecture, and the sight of dozens of strange Pokemon going about their daily lives. As you walked, you passed by a sign welcoming you to Norberry Village. “Whoa…” You breathe as the two of you stop for a moment on the edge of town. “I’ve never seen so many Pokemon in one place before.”

“... how long have you lived around here, again?” She asked, in a deadpan tone.

“Uh… well, my entire life, I guess,” you shrug.

“Oh? And yet you weren’t aware there was an entire village just down the road?” She asked. Judging by her tone, it was obvious she thought she had caught you in a lie. You stutter breathlessly, trying to explain yourself, but you just can’t find the words. She sits there in haunting silence for a while, before sighing. “Whatever. Go ahead and take a hike, kid. You better hope we don’t see eachother around.”

“O-okay,” you stutter as she stands and begins to stalk away. “It was nice to meet you!” You watched the beautiful fox disappear into the crowd waiting until you were sure she was gone before hurriedly wandering in the opposite direction. You were used to living alone in the wilderness, so the sights and sounds of the small village were incredible to you. You try excitedly to ask the various strange Pokemon walking the streets about your parents, but they all seemed to be in a hurry for some reason. A few, however, point you towards the office of the village chief, so you decide to head there first.

You step inside the giant, cozy tent, which was lit up with an array of beautiful candles and lanterns. Your nostrils were immediately filled with the scent of burning incense. Sitting on a tarp on the other side of the tent was a massive goodra, almost the size of the scolipede you ran into earlier. You assumed this was the village chief. She smiled brightly when she saw you walk in. “Well, aren’t you just the cutest little thing!” She says, using her long neck to bring her head down to eye-level. “What’s got you so excited, little guy?”

“This town… it’s amazing!” You smile, impressed by both the beauty of the tent and the sheer size of the village chief.

“Heh! I’m glad you’re settling in well,” the goodra giggles. “We don’t get many absols around here. You know, when I saw you coming, I mistook you for someone else. Does the name ‘Lydia’ ring any bells?”

“Y-yes! Lydia is my mother!” You perk up immediately. “Have you seen her?”

“Oh, really? They never mentioned you,” she said, rubbing her chin. “Well, the two of them passed through here just this morning. Said they were heading to Shipton City.”

“Shipton City?” You tilted your head. “Where’s that?”

“Due east from here. Just look for the eastward route,” she explained. In your excitement, you were just about to hop to your feet and sprint off, but she interrupted you. “But you can’t go wandering around after dark, even if you are Gunnar’s son. You should stay in our inn for the night, just to be safe.” She gives you directions to the local inn, as well as instructions on how to book a place to stay for the night.

“T-thank you so much!” You said graciously as you rushed out the door.

┄┄┄


You walk into the main lobby of the inn, only to freeze in place when you hear the ninetale’s voice. “You can’t be serious!” Sure enough, there she was; that same unmistakable ninetales, yelling angrily at the Pokemon at the front desk. You were about to leave before she saw you, until you noticed her plight.

“Sorry, ma’am, but our inn is for locals only. We don’t need any wild Pokemon scaring the other patrons,” the grumpig that ran the inn said. “You know, Shipton city is just down the road…”

“That’s miles away!” She yelled, her voice alternating between anger and desperation. She looked tense as she loomed over the grumpig, baring her teeth. “I can’t be out in the wilderness at night. I… need somewhere to stay.”

“You’re not planning on making this violent, are you?” The grumpig calmly raised a brow, noticing that the ninetales was on the edge of attacking. A few other Pokemon from around town were standing around the lobby, looking ready to pounce on her if she tried anything. Seeing this, the defeated ninetales forced herself to calm down, backing away from the grumpig. “Listen. Unless you’re friends with any locals, I recommend you just turn tail and--”

“I’m a local!” You announce excitedly, walking up to the front desk. The ninetales shivered in surprise when she heard your voice once again, but remained motionless.

“Oh? Are you?” He looked at you incredulously. “I don’t believe I’ve seen you around town…”

“W-well, maybe you’ve seen my parents,” you insist, nervously. “A zoroark and an absol?”

“Oh? You’re the son of Gunnar?” He raised a brow, surprised. “Well, then! We would be happy to have such an esteemed guest.” He raised a hand, gesturing to the motionless woman. “This, uh… Ninetales. Is she a friend of yours?”

“Uh… yep. She sure is,” you nod immediately, seizing the opportunity.

“Well, why didn’t you just say so?” The grumpig teased the ninetales, who remained completely still, seemingly meditating to relieve her anger. You and the grumpig discuss the inn while she meditates, going over your accommodations for the night. Apparently, the ‘inn’ allows locals to just sleep here for free, presumably to keep the village’s population from being picked off by wild predators in the night. “You two are in the hut with the red roof. Try not to make too much noise!” Once that was all settled, the ninetales stands up as if springing back to life. She makes a move for the door, and you nervously follow after her.

“Can’t believe this shit…” She muttered quietly to herself as she padded silently out the door. You couch awkwardly as the two of you walked towards the huts.

“So, hey, uh… I know you said you didn’t want me around,” you explain. “But you looked like you needed help, y’know?” You hoped she would forgive you, but instead, she remained just as silent as ever. Eventually, the two of you come across a big adobe hut, reinforced with wooden beams, with a big red thatched roof. “Welp… this is it, I guess.” You said, unlocking the big, wooden door and taking a step inside. The interior of the hut was fairly plain; a nest on one end, a barrel bathtub on the other, and little to no furniture inbetween. There were no windows whatsoever, further emphasizing that the purpose of the hut was simple protection against the elements. The ninetales pads silently over to the nest when you walked in, seemingly ignoring you completely. Her silence unnerves you. Had you pissed off one of the first Pokemon you’ve ever met? “I’m… sorry for bothering you. I wasn’t following you, honest! I just… sort of ended up at the inn…”

Hearing the genuine remorse in your voice, the ninetales sighs loudly. “That whole thing wasn’t your fault…” She says over her shoulder. “Thanks for helping out. Don’t know what I would’ve done if you hadn’t shown up.” You perked up when she thanked you. Perhaps the two of you could be friends after all. The ninetales curiously prodded the soft nest with a paw. “So, tell me. Do we really only have one bed in here?”

You were confused by her question for a moment, until you remembered that, of course, she was blind. “Uh, yep,” you answered, awkwardly. “I… could just sleep on the floor, if you want.”

“Heh. That won’t be necessary.”
155222.title: Welcome to Norberry

1552222.content:
“While we’re alone, I feel like I owe you an explanation,” she said, walking over and sitting right on the floor by your side. She lifted one paw over your shoulder as she got down to brass tacks. “Like I said, I’ve got some pretty bad Pokemon after me, so I can’t really trust anyone.” She muttered bitterly. “I know you probably have good intentions and all, but the problem is, how can I be sure you’re not working for ‘em? I mean, what would stop you from just killing me in my sleep?” She leaned in closer, whispering into your ear. “So… why don’t we try a little trust exercise?”

Did she really expect you to prove you weren’t some kind of assassin? You were baffled, but ultimately, curious what this ‘trust exercise’ could be. “Like what?”

“Hear me out. I can’t just sleep while you’re out here in the open. I’d be vulnerable,” she explained, slowly, as if she was picking her every word very carefully. This had the side effect of making her explanation sound… unnatural, like she wasn’t being genuine. “So I would appreciate it, as a gesture of goodwill, if you would spend the night… locked away some place safe.”

She brought your attention down to her stomach, and you remember something. You had heard plenty of tales of savage predators swallowing down their helpless prey… but you’d also heard of Pokemon temporarily storing the ones they love inside them, just to keep them safe. “... you don’t mean…?"

“Yes. Not for very long; just until tomorrow morning,” she said, patting her belly comfortably, “and I’ve done this plenty of times. I can guarantee you’d be completely unharmed,” she points to the door of the hut, “but if you don’t trust me, you can just leave. I won’t stop you.” You noticed something while briefly glancing at the door; it was locked. The Ninetales had no intention of actually letting you walk out of here. She was testing you.

“Can I… take a moment to think about this?” You ask, feeling lightheaded.

“Take as long as you need,” she nods, letting you lean up against her furry belly like a soft pillow as you contemplated the situation.

If you tried to just walk out, would she assume you were some kind of spy, heading out to inform the others of her location? Leaving was a dangerous option, but letting the fox do whatever she pleases was dangerous, too. She was a wild Pokemon, after all. You never knew if this was all some sort of trick to get a midnight snack. You at least attempted to talk your way out of this. “I mean… I-I’m not here to hurt you or a-anything…”

“I know. I just want you to prove it to me,” she says reassuringly, licking over your head a few times while you contemplating, covering your forehead with saliva. Maybe she was planning on eating and digesting you no matter what you did. Or maybe… she really was telling the truth. I mean, if she was just going to digest you, she would’ve pounced on you the moment the two of you were alone. Then again, if she was telling the truth, why did she lock the door when you weren’t looking? As you thought up all the possibilities, you determined that the best response was to just… obey the fox, and hope she has mercy on you.

“O-okay… if it doesn’t hurt,” you nod, finally managing to force the words out of your mouth.

“Thank you, absol. I promise, I’ll be very gentle…” she smiled, but despite her reassurances, you were almost dizzy with fear. She frowns, seeing the look on your face. “If you’re nervous, I’d recommend you just lie down, close your eyes, and relax.” You do as she said, lying down on your back on the comfortable nest, trying to still your beating heart. Eventually, though, just as you were calming down, you hear the floorboards crack as the ninetales repositioned herself. You couldn’t help but take a peek, half-opening one of your eyes only to find yourself staring straight at...
1552222.title: Trust Excercise

15522221.content:
For an instant, you watch the ninetale’s open mouth descending down upon your face with savage speed. Before you could even process what was happening, your entire head was pressed into her gaping maw, your cheek resting on her tongue as you stared, wide-eyed, down her cavernous throat. She seemed to struggling to position your horn in a way that would fit it down her throat, giving you some time to think. You ultimately just froze up, due to the same instincts that cause a cub to freeze up when they’re lifted by the scruff; you know you’d hurt yourself if you tried to escape now, so all you could do was subject yourself to the ninetales’ will. Eventually, your horn was squeezed into her throat at an odd angle, rendering its sharp point harmless. The hard part was over. All that was left was working you down her throat.

When she said she had done this before, she definitely wasn’t kidding. She seemed to work with almost robotic efficiency, falling into a pattern of repeatedly repositioning, taking a big gulp, and then repositioning again. Each swallow took a few inches of your body into her throat. It wasn’t long before your head had created a sizeable bulge in her neck, and the muscles of her throat squeezed down and undulated around it. Her throat felt like there was a conveyer belt wrapped tightly around your head, relentlessly pulling you in one direction -- down towards the vixen’s belly. She couldn’t breathe while your body was blocking her throat, so she had to act fast. It didn’t take an especially long time for your entire upper body to be reduced to an immense bulge in her neck, your head having already disappeared between her muscular shoulders.

You were bombarded by so many sensations as you were squeezed down her throat, it was almost surreal. You were even beginning to feel a little excited. Your felt your shaft poking out of your sheathe, though luckily, she doesn’t seem to notice as it glides over her tongue, or at least she acts like she doesn’t. It’s not like you were a fan of the idea of getting eaten or anything. It was just the sensation of being literally inside of someone, especially someone as exotic and beautiful as the ninetales. You admired her body on the outside, but on the inside, you were given a new perspective entirely -- you could feel the athletic vixen’s powerful muscles squeezing around you, you could hear her calm breathing and the gentle, rhythmic beating of her heart. You had simply never felt this level of understand and connection with another Pokemon before. It felt like the ultimate display of intimacy; like she was being completely honest about her body, by trusting you to enter it completely.

Eventually, she closed her mouth around your hind paws. Every single inch of your body was now shrouded in darkness, and surrounded by sweltering moisture and incredible heat. You were completely inside her, now, your entire life at the mercy of the vixen’s gorgeous, powerful body. At the same moment, your head was pressed into a large sac that you assumed was her stomach. It was identical, in many ways, to her throat; the only difference being that it was much roomier, and the walls and bottom were soaked with a myriad of strange liquids. With one final gulp, you’re pulled inside her stomach completely, stretching it to its limits. Now that the obstruction in her throat had finally cleared, the ninetales was finally able to speak. After gasping for air for a few moments, she gasped as she felt you immediately start wriggling around inside her. “Oh! Oh! Settle down in there, absol…”

She moaned loudly, feeling you squirm within her sensitive belly before she was prepared. Thinking you were hurting here, you stopped your wriggling for a moment, simply curling up inside of her. “There you go. That’s it. See? It’s not so bad,” she reassures you in an almost motherly sort of tone. She rubs her belly contentedly, and you’re delighted by the realization that you can feel her paws from the inside. You try to call out to her, but your voice doesn’t seem to escape the thick walls. “Are you trying to say something? I’m sorry, but I’m not going to be able to hear you until I let you out in the morning.” You were a little startled by this knowledge. What if something went wrong? If she couldn’t hear you shouting, would she even notice before it was too late? “Just try to get comfortable in there. Get some rest. I’ll be seeing you tomorrow.” You sighed. She was right. No point in worrying about it now. You were past the point of no return.

Comforted by the weight in her gut, the ninetales went into a deep feed coma within minutes… but even after a half hour passed, you definitely couldn’t fall asleep. Your manhood had grown painfully hard, and it didn’t seem like it would be calming down anytime soon. Would it… really be right to just paw yourself off while you’re inside the vixen’s body? She was asleep, so it’s not like she’s consenting to such a thing… but on the other hand, if she ate you, she couldn’t really care what you do while you’re inside her belly, right? Eventually unable to resist temptation any longer, you bring your forepaws down around your shaft on both sides, and gently slide them up and down the pink flesh painfully slowly, trying not to rouse the fox for her slumber. You just wanted to get this over with, so you could get some sleep. At least, that’s what you tell yourself.

As time passed, the ninetale’s stomach slowly began to contract around her ‘prisoner’, the walls squeezing in tighter and tighter around you. You weren’t even concerned by this, too distracted by your own pleasure. Just feeling your shaft brush up against the walls of the ninetale’s stomach for a moment sent shivers down your spine. You can’t help but change things up a bit; using your forepaws to press your shaft against the soft, malleable walls of her stomach, before grinding in earnest. The feeling was extraordinary, much better than anything you could do with your own paws. Your gasps and squeaks were drowned out by the churning and gurgling of the ninetale’s stomach as it squeezed even tighter around you. On the outside, your shaft created a prominent bulge in the side of the vixen’s distended belly as you eagerly humped the interior.

It didn’t take very long for the soft, wet walls to push you over the edge. Your body tensed up as you were hit by the greatest climax you’ve experienced in your life, your load fading away among the assortment of other gastric juices already bearing down on you. You lean back in her stomach, panting as your satisfied manhood retreats back into your sheathe. Now that you’re finally thinking straight, you begin to feel a little concerned. Was it… supposed to be this tight in here? It used to be downright roomy, but by now you could hardly move a muscle, and her belly was only contracting around you more and more with no sign of stopping. On the outside, her big, round belly had contracted into a very clear imprint of your body, the furry flesh moving and undulated as your squirmed around with what little wriggle room you had left.

There was a puddle of gastric acid in a pool at the bottom of her stomach, you noticed. It was about half an inch deep, and barely even tingled; still, it was a concerning sight. Being digested never seemed like an especially pleasant fate. Unfortunately, it wasn’t like there was anything you could do about it now. You could only drift off to sleep, and trust that the ninetales was going to keep her promise…

Do you survive the night?
15522221.title: Sleeping Somewhere Warm

155222211.content:
That night, you dreamt you were curled up in a giant bubble of air, floating aimlessly through an endless, clear, beautiful blue ocean. You dreamt you were back in the womb, tucked away far away from the horrors and violence of the outside world. You dreamt that you and the ninetales were adrift in an endless field of flowers, and the two of you made love. You dreamt all sorts of wonderful things, and for the first night in years, you were truly at peace.

Your dreams evoked such joy that you were genuinely disappointed when a jostling roused you from your slumber. You were confused, for a moment, when you first woke up and found yourself in a dark, tight chamber, but then you remembered the events of the previous night. It was almost surreal to actually wake up again, when a part of you was certain that you were doomed. “Sorry to interrupt, sleepyhead. I would gladly let you lounge around in there all day, but it’s a little dangerous to stay in there for too long,” you heard her beautiful voice emanate through the soft walls, “so I’m going to cough you up now, okay? So… get ready.”

You take some time to get your bearings, as you return from one of the deepest, most refreshing rests you’ve ever had. You must’ve been sleeping for over a dozen hours, and you’re still tingling with joy over all the dreams you had. In fact, looking down, it seems you may have enjoyed them a little too much. Your manhood was unsheathed and at attention once again, even though you had just woken up seconds ago. You were amused by this at first, for a moment, until you remembered that the ninetales was just about to cough you up! You try to hold yourself in place, but it’s futile.

She dry heaves, and you feel like your tiny little prison within her is turned inside out all at once. Suddenly, the unrelenting muscles of her throat were squeezed around your body again, this time pulling you up instead of down. She hacked and coughed as you proceeded up her neck. You gasped out when you realized the soft walls of her throat were pressed so incredibly tight against your shaft, too, further exacerbating your little problem. It takes a bit of your willpower to resist just cumming right then and there, while you were a simple bulge in the vixen’s throat. Eventually, your snout enters her maw, and you were finally able to look at the outside world once again.

The view from the back of her throat was incredible, but unfortunately, it didn’t last long. With a final, nauseating lurch, the rest of your body is forced from the ninetail’s throat all in one movement. You were quite literally ejected onto the cold, hard wooden floor, in a big puddle of saliva and sizzling gastric acid. You were soaked to the bone with various juices of all imaginable stenches and viscosities, but you were more concerned with your morning wood, until you remembered… her blindfold! Of course she wasn’t going to notice your little situation. You didn’t even bother to try hiding it as you pulled yourself to your feet, shaking off the liquids.

The ninetails was coughing and sputtering, her throat severely sore from the agonizing process of spitting you out. “Ugh! Hurts a lot more comin’ up than going down…” She eventually said, composing herself. She flinches when you shake yourself dry. “Hm. You smell like you could probably use a good shower.” Compared to how filthy she was yesterday, he fur was pristine today, so she must’ve taken a shower while you were inside her belly.

“A… shower?” You said, only to cringe when a bit of pre dripped onto the floor. “Y-yes! A shower! Okay!” You hurried to turn on the primitive showerhead -- a faucet suspended above a grate, distributing the water evenly over those below -- and sat beneath it, shivering in the cold. You simply rinse for a while, watching the ninetails as she gets ready for the coming day, and, once you were convinced she wasn’t listening, you gently wrap your paws around both sides of your shaft once again. You just wanted to get this out of your system as quickly as possible -- which was difficult, since you had to stroke your paws up and down unbearably slowly to avoid alerting the vixen.

Comfortable in the knowledge that she couldn’t see you, you squeeze your eyes shut, trying to pretend that the vixen wasn’t just a few feet away while you were pawing yourself off. Unfortunately, she didn’t make it very easy for you. “Well, now I know I can trust you, at least,” she said over her shoulder, making you tense up at the sound of her voice. “You’re definitely not one of Marden’s goons. They definitely would not have the balls to agree to that little ‘trust exercise’.”

“Yeah,” is the only thing you said aloud. Please stop talking, please stop talking, please stop talking, was what you were actually thinking in your head. You didn’t understand anything she was saying, but you decide not to question it till after you’re finished with your ‘shower’. You peek one of your eyes open to keep tabs on what the ninetales is doing, only to realize she was facing the other way, bent over as she reorganizes the nest. Your heart leaps in your chest as you suddenly get an extraordinary view of her firm but still quite rounded ass, and while you turn away as fast as you could, the image was seared into your mind.

Like it or not, the ninetales was one of the most attractive Pokemon you’ve ever met. It didn’t hurt that she was one of the only Pokemon you’ve ever really befriended, after eighteen years of utter isolation in the wilderness had left you starved for companionship. Her scars may be disturbing to most Pokemon, but in your eyes, they only made you admire her more. Of course, you couldn’t fantasize about her. You knew her! What kind of disrespect would that be? You try to imagine a random lopunny or liepard instead, but still, your thoughts always drifted back to the ninetales. Especially to that one dream you had the night before. You couldn’t remember all the details of that dream, but you remembered that her blindfold was taken off to reveal her beautiful, perfect blue eyes, and you definitely remembered the look of love and joy in those eyes as you mounted her.

It took quite a while, but even at this pace, you were so horny that you were finally able to bring yourself to climax all along the floor of the makeshift shower, just a couple yards away from the oblivious vixen. Your load blended in with the water and filtered down the drain as you sat there, holding your breath, trying not to make a sound even as your body was overloaded with the sensation. Eventually, you were resting your eyes while leaning against the back wall of the shower, all of your energy and enthusiasm gone, with only your shame remaining. You snicker as your manhood slips slowly back into your sheathe. You thought to yourself that that’s all this was -- taking care of a basic, biological necessity. Nothing more.

By this point, you’d been in the shower for so long, the water alone had rinsed you clean completely. With all that out of the way, you were ready to start your morning for real. You and the ninetales silently sat around for a breakfast of tanga berries, and by the time it was finished, you were right back to your old self. “Sooo, uh…” You ask awkwardly, interrupting her meditation. “I forgot to ask, but… who’s Marden?”

She sighs at the question. “Some asshole kommo-o,” she growled, pointing at her blindfold. “All you need to know is that he did this to me. And now he wants me dead.” You were now more curious than ever to see what was under that blindfold. Did she have some kind of disfiguring injury? You figure it would be rude to ask, though, so you try not be nosy.

“Hm…” You said, unable to come up with an appropriate response. You decide to just change the subject. “So, where are you heading to, next?”

“I have some business to attend to in Shipton city.”

“Really?” Your ears perk up, and you smile. “I’m heading there too! My parents are probably there. Maybe we could travel together… y’know, keep each other company? Now that you trust me an' all...”

She looked in your general direction for a while, her expression unreadable, before smiling a big, toothy grin. “Alright,” she says, “but if you want to travel with me, I’m going to need to teach you a thing or two about combat…”
155222211.title: Good Morning

1552222111.content:
The two of you capped off your visit to Norberry with a trip to the local tavern. Compared to the grumpig you two met earlier, the rest of the citizens of the village seemed surprisingly friendly, and seemed eager to entertain their guests. You and the ninetales enjoyed some delicious berry juice as an elderly unfezant regaled you with fascinating tales of her past adventures, and while a hilarious sandslash fellow showed off his juggling skills with some berries, and while the slowbro at the counter demonstrated the process behind some of his delicious recipes. In just a couple of hours of hanging out at the tavern, you were surrounded by more friendly Pokemon than you’ve ever met before today. Even the goodra was there, taking a break from her duties to chat with her village’s citizens. You noticed something, though; at one point, the ninetales seemed to be whispering something in the goodra’s ear. The goodra looked outraged, and nodded dutifully, before immediately trudging out of the tavern towards the inn. You didn’t know what that was all about, but you couldn’t be bothered to ask.

It was fun, but eventually, it was time for you both to leave. You had to get to Shipton by sundown, after all. The two of you stumbled out of the gates of the tavern with smiles on your faces, still amused by the antics of the locals. You were still just winding down while you made your way over to the eastward route. “So, what are you heading to Shipton city for?” You ask, realizing you haven’t had much of a chance to talk with the ninetales one-on-one yet today.

“Marden’s goons practically runs the streets there. I figure I should take the fight straight to them.”

“Sounds like… a pretty dangerous plan,” you comment. You don’t want to be judgemental or anything, but if they have the whole city under their control, there must be a small army of them. “I mean, can you really take them all on by yourself?”

“No, but I can definitely pick ‘em off one by one. In a big city like that, there are plenty of places to hide,” she said, but seemed to want to change the subject. “How about you? Tryin’ to reunite with your parents, right?”

“Reunite? Nah. I just want to figure out what the hell they were thinking when they ditched me,” you laugh, awkwardly, feeling kind of pathetic when you heard the words from your own mouth. “Bastards ain’t gettin’ rid of me that easy!”

“Oooh! I like your spunk!” She laughed along, bumping you in the side. “Travellin’ for miles and miles just to flip off your folks. I like it.” She stopped suddenly when you walked by the inn. “Well, before we head out, there’s one last thing I wanna check out.”

“Alright, lead the way,” you nodded, following the ninetales back up the hill to the inn. When you got there, the inn lobby was… exactly the same. The only thing of interest was that goodra was there, seemingly chatting with the grumpig at the front desk. “... huh. Is this what you wanted to see?”

“Quiet!” She whispered, urgently. You went silent for a while, straining your ears, only to realize that the goodra and the grumpig were arguing passionately over something.

“I’ve told you to cut the ‘locals only’ policy,” the chieftain was saying calmly, looming tall over the defiant grumpig. There was anger in her voice, but it was… restrained, as if she was simply disappointed. “Our village is supposed to be open to all Pokemon!”

“The citizens of Norberry deserve to feel safe!” The grumpig, on the other hand, was shouting angrily at the top of his lungs for everyone in the village to hear. “But how could they, when there are savages running around town in the night?”

“We’ve had no 'incidents' with wild Pokemon.”

“Sure, we’ve gotten lucky. But how long is that going to last? We let it in just one wrong Pokemon, and villagers will die. Your weakness is going to get us all killed one day!”

“Prisco, I advise you have some respect for your chieftain.” The normally light-hearted goodra was talking with the calmest tone she could muster, trying to defuse the situation. You could tell, though, that as the grumpig complained louder and louder, the goodra’s patience was rapidly running thin.

“You may have inherited that title, but you’ve done nothing to make us respect it,” he growled. “These savages are a danger to every single one of us, and I won’t listen to a damn word you say until- ah!” His furious rant was interrupted when the goodra easily lifted him up with a hand. She seemed to hug the grumpig against her body, confusing you for a moment… until you noticed that he seemed to be being consumed by the purple goo of the dragon’s belly.

“Sounds like the only danger here is you,” she said, looking down at the helpless grumpig.

“W-whoa! What… what the hell are you doing?” He says, trying to push against the goo, only for his arms to be submerged. “Let me go!” The goodra pressed him against her with greater and greater force, until his face was submerged in the viscous goo, muffling his furious cries. You watch in awe as the goodra’s body just seemed to slide around him, surrounding him on all sides. Eventually, he was submerged completely, the goo of her belly jiggling as it slid back into place, sealing the grumpig inside her. Her belly was slightly transparent, too, so you could see the outline of the grumpig as he wriggled around inside. You watched with fascination as the goodra rubbed contentedly over her enlarged belly, almost excited by the sight.

“Sorry, ol’ pal. You’re stayin’ in there until you learn some respect,” the goodra says, licking her ‘lips’. Her belly seemed to become less and less transparent as the goo solidified, until eventually it was completely opaque, sealing the grumpig from the outside world. “A few weeks, maybe. Don’t worry; I can take care the inn while you’re away...” Satisfied, the chieftain walked away, the citizens of her village staring in awe as one of them squirmed around inside her distended belly. They certainly wouldn’t be disrespecting the chieftain any time soon.

“Did you see it? What happened?” The ninetales asked, sounding excited. You realized that the ninetales had probably engineered this whole thing, apparently as a sort of vengeance.

“She just… sort of sucked him into her belly, I guess,” you shrug, still shaken by what you had witnessed. “Sounds like he’s going to be in there for a while.”

“Hah! Awesome!” She smiled that same toothy grin, apparently taking a sort of sadistic glee in the grumpig’s misery. “If it were me, I woulda just churned ‘em up into fat. But I guess this is good enough.” Apparently, the ninetales doesn’t like being judged for being a ‘wild Pokemon’. She beams with satisfaction over her victory for a few moments, before noticing how impatient you were. “Alright, alright. We can get movin’ now…” The two of you stroll out the gates of Norberry, travelling down the long, winding route leading eastward through the wilderness. You were excited to leave, but you’ve also enjoyed your time in the village. Maybe, when this was all over and one with, you could come visit again...
1552222111.title: Unfinished Business

15522221111.content:
“The first rule of combat is that there are no rules.”

The two of you had been walking down the route for about an hour now, and the ninetales was finally about ready to go over that combat training she promised. Unfortunately, within the first ten seconds, you were already confused. “You lost me already. Doesn’t that rule cancel itself out?” You look to her, tilting your head curiously. “If there’s a rule that states there are no rules, that just means there may or may not be rules…”

“The second rule of combat is ‘don't be a smartass’,” she replied, deadpan. From the tone of her voice, if she was capable of rolling her eyes, she definitely would be. “Seriously, though. I don’t know what your folks taught ya, but out here, you have to play dirty. Go for the throat, go for the eyes, take ‘em by surprise, the works.” She stepped out in front of you, stopping you in your tracks. It was time to get down to business. “So, tell me. What can you do?”

You stare blankly at her. “What do you mean?”

“What can you do?” She leaned in closer. “Razor wing? Perish song? Swords dance? What?”

“I don’t really know,” your face flushed with embarrassment. An experienced survivor like the ninetales was probably going to think you’re pathetic. “I’ve… never really been in a fight before…”

“You’ve… never been in a fight before,” she repeated, deadpan, as if she couldn’t believe the words until she heard them from her own mouth. She turned away from you with a resigned snort, her disappointment palpable. “Arceus…”

“I-I’m sorry!” You insist, devastated by her reaction. The ninetales was… probably the coolest Pokemon you’ve ever met. Part of you desperately wanted to her approval. “I’ve just… always preferred hiding, you know?”

She paused, silent for a while, before turning towards you again. “Alright, then,” she said, her tone unreadable. “Let me see you hide.”

“W-what?”

“Go hide somewhere. You have thirty seconds. Let me see what you can do.”

“Uh, okay!” You were surprised by a sudden time limit, but you were desperate to prove yourself in something at least. You rushed away into the overgrowth, disoriented, and quickly decide to imitate the same technique the ninetales used when you were hiding from the scolipede. You try to silently dig your way beneath a particularly overgrown path of weeds and shrubbery. By the time you were completely covered, you were feeling pretty confident about your hiding space. Not even an inch of your body was exposed from any angle, and there was no evidence of what you had done. Satisfied, you settled in as you waited for your time to run out, holding your breath, trying not to make a sound.

“Time’s up,” she announced, before leaning her head back, loudly sniffing the air. “... is that the best you can do?” Your heart skipped a beat when she immediately turned and walked directly to your hiding spot. Of course! She can smell you! You looked up at her from your spot in the dirt, feeling pathetic. “What did you even do, exactly? Hide under a bush? Why? I’m blind.” You cringed at your own stupidity. You had just copied what the ninetales had done. You hadn’t even considered that different predators might require a different technique. “Meanwhile, you hid downwind of me. I can smell you from here.”

Your curiosity distracted you from your wounded pride. “Downwind? W-what does that mean?”

She stands there in disbelief, before sighing, covering her face with a paw. “This is going to take longer than I thought…”

For the next hour or two, ninetales described and demonstrated all the basics of hiding, showing you how to disappear into the background of the forest, how to move silently over uneasy ground, and how to stay upwind of your predator. Despite her apparent exasperation earlier, in practice, she was a patient and effective teacher. Of course, she couldn't teach you everything in just this span. You still couldn't move nearly as quietly as she did, not did you have any idea how to hide from, say, a flying-type Pokemon, or a ghost-type. Still, you got the basics down. Eventually, she’s taught you all you need to know for many encounters, and the two of you were chilling out in the wilderness, winding down. “Alright, alright, you’ve made some progress,” she admits with a smile. “We’re going to have to wrap this up soon, so let’s cap this off with a little exam.”

“Exam?”

She stands up, suddenly looming over you. “I’ll pretend to be some hostile predator for, say, five minutes. I’ll give my best effort to catch you, you’ll give your best effort to hide,” she explains. “If you’re not inside my belly by the time the five minutes are over, you passed.”

“Inside… your…?”

“Yep! Oh, by the way, this exam’s happening whether you like it or not, pal,” she smirks, licking her lips teasingly. “So, uh… might want to take advantage of that head start.” You groan. Here we go again, you think as you stand up and dart into the forest once more. This time, even though she promised she’d be giving it her all, you were still pretty confident. How hard could it be to hide from her? As long as you stay upwind and don’t make a sound, it’s just not possible for her to detect you, even when you’re walking out in the open. As you contemplate the rules of your little ‘test’, a part of you wanted to just sit back and let her catch you. Her warm belly would be a great place to spend the rest of your trip. It would sure beat the hell out of walking. On the other hand, though, you really wanted to impress the ninetales, and this might be a prime opportunity. Plus, if she swallows you, there was always the chance, however slim, that she might end up digesting you, intentionally or otherwise.

Ultimately, you decide to just give this whole thing your best shot. You disappear into the white noise of the wilderness, and hear the ninetales howling in the distance, signifying that the ‘test’ had begun. Even now, she was sprinting silently through the wilderness, tracking your scent and straining her ears for snapping twigs or brushing leaves. You were going to have to think fast to make it through this one...
15522221111.title: Combat Training

155222211111.content:
The test proved more difficult than you expected. The ninetales scoured the forest relentlessly, forcing you to constantly keep moving; plus, she was completely silent as she sprinted through the wilderness, making her extremely hard to keep track of. It was only by an incredible measure of luck that you managed to evade her for even just a few seconds; actually making it for five minutes seemed like it would take a miracle. Still, as you hid, you learned her patterns, and her weaknesses. For example, she definitely couldn’t see you -- not even in some weird sonar sense -- so you could just walk out into the open without any risk of being spotted. You didn’t keep any track of the time that had passed, so when the five minutes were up, it took you completely by surprise. “Absol! Absol!” The ninetales called out while you were busy hiding beneath a fallen tree log. “Come out, buddy. You passed.”

For a moment, you thought she was just trying to trick you. Once you thought about it, though, you had actually been hiding out here for quite a long time, so five minutes wasn’t an unreasonable estimate. “Really?” You called out to her, excitedly. Had you really made it?

“Yep. Good hustle out there,” she patted you on the shoulder when you returned to her side. Honestly, though, she sounded a little disappointed. Was she hoping you would fail? “You’ve definitely learned a lot.”

“To be honest, I thought I didn’t stand a chance,” you smiled, wiping the sweat off your forehead in relief. You figure, though, that if she gets a bellyful of absol if you lost, you should at least get some sort of prize for winning. “Do I get anything for winning?”

“What? What the hell do I even have to giveI-” She says, before stopping herself. “Actually, nevermind. Your reward is the warm, fuzzy feeling you get whenever I, in my infinite mercy, don’t swallow you up and churn you up into fat. Is that satisfactory?” She answered sarcastically.

“Yep!” You smile, skipping back towards the path. When you made it back to the route, you noticed that it seemed pretty late in the afternoon. “Uh… isn’t it getting a little late?”

“Yeah, I was just about to mention that,” she sighed. “I may have lost track of time, there, so… we’re definitely not making it to Shipton by sundown.” You shudder, remembering all the stories your folks told you of the horrific predators that roam the wilderness at night. Despite the seriousness of the situation, the ninetales nudged you in the side with a sly smile. “On the upside, you’ll probably get to put those new hiding skills to use, huh?” With that, she continued down the winding path as if there was nothing to worry about, leaving you in the dust. You grimace as you hurry after her, unable to get over your anxiety despite her confidence. Hopefully you’ll be able to find shelter, or else the both of you might be doomed after all...
155222211111.title: Passing Grade

1552222111111.content:
A humble monastery lay nestled along the route to Shipton. Its roofs were triangular and towered slightly over the trees, and its interiors were lit by gorgeous lanterns, kept going by a constant flow of a magical energy. The building itself was surprisingly open for a building so exposed to the elements, with long windows and open doorways. Most notable was the big sign by its entrance - ‘Travellers Welcome!’

You and the ninetales were sitting on a nearby hill, overlooking the monastery. It was very late at night, at this point, and the two of you were panting with exhaustion and desperate for a place to rest. You squinted, watching the Pokemon inside the monastery from a distance, describing them to the ninetales. They were all dressed in strange religious garments, and despite the time, they seemed to be having some sort of jovial feast. “They look… trustworthy,” you comment to the ninetales. Their smiles and laughter were so bright and genuine, and their uniforms so beautiful and mysterious, you kind of wanted to hang out with them just to see what this whole thing was about.

“Ehhh,” she shrugged, uncertainly. “I don’t know.”

“... alright.” Seeing she wasn’t satisfied, you scope the place out again. The two of you are silent for a while again, until something new of interest happens. “Huh. Now they’re all kneeling down in front of some sort of… statue?” You raise a brow.

“They’re worshippers,” she replied. “Couldn’t tell you who they’re worshipping, though. They have cults for all kinds of Pokemon. Arceus, Mesprit, Giratina…” You nodded contemplatively as she explained it. You knew that certain Pokemon were revered, but you were never aware they were worshipped in such an organized manner.

“Sounds like you’re not a big fan.”

“I just don’t get the hype,” she shrugs. “Yeah, legendaries are powerful, but they’re not exactly paragons of virtue. Don’t see how power alone makes you worth worshipping.”

“Well, the point stands that we need somewhere to hide out,” you insist, “and this looks as good as any.”

The ninetales is silent for a while, trying to come up with a good counterargument, only to come up short. “... I don’t know if I want to spend the night around a bunch of cultists,” was all she could say.

“Well, would you rather spend the night in some scolipede’s colon?”

After a moment of silence, she sighs in frustration, pulling herself up to her paws. “... fine. Let’s go check it out,” she begrudgingly agreed, unable to argue with that logic. The two of you trotted down the hill to the monastery, stepping out of the darkness, bathed in the beautiful blue lanterns that lit up the entryway. Standing in the huge, intricate room at the fore of the monastery was a huge braviary, draped in the most beautiful arrangements of robes and ornaments you’ve ever seen. Every inch of the huge bird’s outfit was engraved with beautiful symbols and patterns, hinting at some higher purpose. Her eyes fluttered open soon after you walk in, apparently hearing you enter.

“Oh, my! It seems we have some visitors!” She smiled, looking down at the two of you. Even the ninetales looked tiny in comparison. She shifts her gigantic wings as she wakes, but ultimately remains in place. “Welcome to the Shipton monastery. What brings you to our sleepy little order tonight?”

You assume the ninetales was going to say something, but she seemed wholly apathetic, so you had to answer for her. “We were just heading into the city, and we’re running a little behind schedule…” You explain. “We’re wondering if you know of anywhere we can spend the night.”

“Well, you’re perfectly welcome to stay here, if you so desire,” she smiled, spreading her wings as if literally welcoming you into her embrace. “The sisters are busy with their nightly ritual at the moment, but one will be with you shortly.”

“Oh, sweet, thank you!” You say. You glance at all the books and artifacts arranged around the room while you wait. You’d honestly never seen a place as beautiful as this little monastery -- the craftsmanship was staggering! “So, uh… what exactly do you do here?”

“Oh, I am Alda the Venerable. I am the abbess of this monastery,” she explains, her voice deep but almost motherly in inflection. “Here, we practice humility, introspection, and open love under the guidance of Cresselia.”

“Cresselia?”

“Cresselia is an aspect of the moon, and the weaver of all pleasant, meaningful dreams. We use the visions she sends us in the night to learn more about our own nature, and the nature of the world.”

You consider it for a while. You’d never thought one Pokemon could have all that power. “Interesting…”

Eventually, heavy doors on the other side of grand room slid open, and a menagerie of oddly-dressed Pokemon stepped out, spreading through the room as they return to their duties. “Ah, there they are.” Alma smiles, turning to her sisters and waving a wing. “Silvia! Oh, Silvia!” She calls. “Come here, please!”

One of them perks up at the sound of their name. This ‘Silvia’ trotted over dressed in similar patterned black robes as the rest of her sisters. Her thick hood and the ornate black veil draped over her face made it hard to determine her species, but when she drew closer, you recognized her as a persian. Everything about her, from the way she walked to the humble smile on her face, indicated that she was the pinnacle of grace and refinement. “Yes, miss Alda?” The persian said, kneeling before the great bird, humble.

“These two weary travellers are looking for a place to stay,” Alda instructing, gesturing towards the two of you with a wing. “I think it would befit your penance if you were to host them for the night. Don’t you agree?”

“Of course, miss Alda,” she nodded without a moment’s hesitation.

“Sister Silvia here will show you around the monastery,” Alda turned towards you again, satisfied with her answer. “Please, try not to touch anything.”

“Right this way,” Silvia turned to you, gesturing both of her visitors to follow her as she gave you a tour of the monastery. A grand library full of ancient knowledge, a cafeteria where all kinds of delicious-smelling exotic goods were being enjoyed, a workshop where gorgeous monuments of devotion were being constructed… every room she led you through seemed more beautiful than the last! You were in love with this place by the time her tour concluded, and she was leading you towards the dorms. “... and these are my accommodations. You may stay here for as long as you’d like,” she finished the tour with, as she pushed open a quaint little wooden door. You peeked inside, only to find that the persian’s room was spartan compared to the rest of the monastery. Just a bed, a bathroom, a lantern, and a few books dotted the tiny wooden room.

This was disappointing to you, but to the ninetales, the basic room was a breath of fresh air compared to the opulence of the rest of the monastery. She slid past you, immediately crashing on the refreshingly old, crappy little wooden bed. You chuckle at this, before turning to the persian. “Thanks for showing us around. This is a really beautiful place you all have here.”

She stared at you for a moment, as if surprised that you were even bothering to talk to her. “I-it was no problem at all, really,” she says, in that same, constant soft, polite tone. You didn’t quite know what her deal was.

The night was still young, and it wasn’t like you had to get up particularly early tomorrow. Uncertain of what you should be doing, you like to your two new ‘roommates’ of sort, seeing how they’re deciding to spend their night. The ninetales seems to be just interested in having dinner, getting washed off, and lounging around. The persian, on the other hand, was wandering down the hall as you speak, diligently returning to whatever duties she had scheduled. You wanted to spend the night with the ninetales, since this might be the last night you see eachother before you have to part ways. Then again, you kind of wanted to see what the persian was up to, and learn more about the curious little monastery.

How do you decide to spend the night?
1552222111111.title: Communion of Cresselia

15522221111111.content:
“So… this is a nice little place, isn’t it?”

“Guess you could say that…” She shrugged, but was apparently much more interested in discussing something else. “So, hey. Can’t help but be curious… what’s the deal with your folks?”

“Well, I mean, you know how it is. Growing up wasn't fun. Dad was a narcissist, mom was a pushover,” you explain. “They just kept me hidden away in their den all day, every day, and did the bare minimum to keep me alive. Now that I’m technically an adult, I guess I’m not their problem anymore, so they just left me to die out here.”

“So you’re not a big fan of your ol’ pops, huh?” she asks, in a weird, uncertain tone. “Well… you wouldn’t mind if I ate him them, would you?”

“W-what do you mean?” You gasped, shocked. Why would she even ask such a question? Thousands of possible explanations passed through your mind, and none of them were pleasant.

“The grumpig said you were son of Gunnar, right?” She says, leaning in closer, her tone deathly serious. “Gunnar works for Marden.”

Yeah, that was one of the possibilities you were afraid of. It certainly brought a lot of things into clarity. He always did seem to busy ‘busy’ with something. “Oh… Arceus,” you said, your eyes wide as you digest this new information.

“I’m not saying that I’m hunting for him or anything… but if we run into eachother, and he attacks me… who knows what would happen?” She frowns. “Just… thought I should give you a warning.”

You were a little uncomfortable with it at first. I mean, he’s your father, right? You didn’t want him to get eaten! Then again, did that really matter? He obviously never even wanted to be your father in the first place. It’s not like he raised you out of the sheer goodness of his heart. You had to be rational about this. “No, no… do what you have to do,” you shake your head, “but I need an explanation of this ‘Marden’ business. A real explanation.”

She nods, thoughtfully. “Yeah. I guess I owe you that much.” She sighs, as if preparing to discuss something she didn’t particularly like to recall. “When I was about your age, I got in on ground zero of this little gang Marden was running. Y’see, back then, ‘wild’ Pokemon were banned from entering most cities. Marden convinced us we’d be able to take those cities over from the inside,” she explained. “I pretty quickly became his right-hand woman, and for a few years, we were mates. Of course, it all fell apart when I realized he was a fuckin’ psychopath.”

She paused, and you urged her to continue. “Hm?”

“He always had an extremely… short temper, and quick to leap to violence. I could convince myself that I deserved it, at least. But when I saw what he did to other, innocent Pokemon…” She seemed to pause and shudder for a while, recalling grim memories. “When he learned I was trying to leave, he… well and truly lost it. For example…” She leaned over and brought a paw around the back of her head, undoing her little red blindfold.

You physically reeled back in shock as the ninetales faced without her blindfold for the first time. You expected that she had some sort of injury, but you were surprised to realize that her eyes were gone completely. Gone very cleanly too; they obviously hadn’t been ripped out, but surgically removed. From a distance, it would look like she just had strange pink slits for eyes, but looking closer, you noticed her eyelids hovered halfway open to reveal the hollow sockets. There was no blood, or scars, or deformation, or any of the other things you would’ve expected. It was just… pink. “W-what did…?”

“He had them… removed, so I could never escape him,” she said, bitterly, as you stared in both awe and terror. “Of course, I escaped his dumb ass anyway.”

You were shocked, but her explanation didn’t fully sate your curiosity. After all, if she was already blind, one question remained. “Why the blindfold…?”

15522221111111.title: Revelations

155222211111111.content:
Fifteen minutes later, you’re finishing up, and open the bathroom door to see the persian was just sitting there the entire time, waiting patiently for her chance to take a shower. You flinched a bit, startled to see her there. “I-I’m sorry!” She whispered frantically, seeing the look on your face.

“No, no, it’s fine. Y’just startled me,” you smile, stepping out of the way. “Your turn, I guess. C’mon in, water’s fine.” You watched the contours of her sleek body beneath her robes as she slid past you into the cramped bathroom, before stepping out and closing the door behind you, giving the feline some privacy. You roll around on a towel for several minutes, drying off your fur, before finally climbing up onto the other side of the bed, across from the ninetales. It was a pretty small bed, obviously only meant for one person, so you didn’t have much room to work with. It didn’t help that the ninetales was already deep in slumber by now, and lying on her side, taking up a sizeable chunk of the bed. Just as you were getting comfortable, you hear the shower turn off, and the persian emerges.

You were surprised when you saw her exit the bathroom. She had taken her robes and veil off for the night, revealing her sylphlike, curvy body in all its glory beneath the dull lantern light. You were astounded by her beauty; it was almost a shame she hid away beneath her robes all the time, following her ideals of humility. Her glowing yellow eyes blinked in the darkness as she crept silently towards the door of the room, as if trying to sneak out without being noticed. “Where ya going?” You whisper, and she freezes.

“I-I was just going to sleep outside,” she whispers back, turning towards you. “I don’t want to disturb you two.”

“What? Nonsense! You don’t have to go sleep somewhere else. This is your room, isn’t it?” You laughed, quietly. “We don’t want to kick you out of your own room or anything.”

She stares at you for a while, as if confused, before shrugging. “If that’s what you truly wish, then I will do as you say,” she said, deadpan, slowly and silently padding over the floor towards the bed. In that moment, you immediately regretted inviting her to stay. How were the three of you going to fit into this tiny, crappy little bed? It was too late now, though. You scooted over, lying on your back, pressing your side against the ninetale’s belly, giving the persian as much room as you possibly could. She ended up having to snuggle up very, very close to you, just to avoid falling off the bed completely. You worried she would be uncomfortable with this sleeping arrangement, as you were complete strangers, but she didn’t seem to mind in the slightest. “Goodnight, absol.”

“Goodnight,” you whisper quietly. Within moments, she had passed out as well, obviously exhausted by a full day of work... leaving you wide awake, sandwiched tightly between the rounded, fluffy bellies of the two beautiful Pokemon. It was… nice. You’d basically been in solitary confinement for so long, you thought you just didn’t need anybody else. But over the past couple days, you’ve begun to realize just how desperately deprived you were of physical contact. ┄┄┄

That night, you dreamt that you were young again, but your father had never entered your life, so you and your mother could live happily in the woods together, and she’d curl up around you and sing you songs as you nestled by the campfire. You dreamt you were surrounded by loved ones, all nuzzling close to one another, and you were happy together. You dreamt many comfortable little dreams, and peace flowed through your body once again.

You were rocked back into the real world by the sounds of destruction. You could hear screaming and fighting in the distance, and your nostrils burned with the smell of smoke. You looked around, in a daze, to realize that your two companions were gone, having left you alone in your bed. All the gentle comfort and cozy satisfaction in your body was replaced with fear and confusion. You rushed over to the door, pulling it open just in time to see two Sisters of the monastery rushing down the hall, dressed in some sort of armor. A cacophony of sounds was erupting from all sides of the monastery, and you had no idea what was happening or where you should go. Confused, you decide following after the Sisters was a good place to start. Looking over the carnage of the partially destroyed monastery and overhearing their frantic conversations, you start to piece together what was going on.

The Scolipede had apparently tracked the ninetales here, and knew this would be the last chance to take her out before she disappeared off the grid completely. Thus, she’d rounded up an entire posse to attack the monastery head-on early in the morning, planning to block off all exits and devour everyone inside, one by one, taking the ninetales alive. Fortunately, Marden’s goons ended up meeting much more resistance than they expected. You looked frantically out a window, to see a small army of Sisters in armor taking cover behind trees and debris, trying to prevent the goons from even entering the monastery. You watched in awe as the braviary battled fiercely with the scolipede, the two giants clashing with fire and fury, and shivered mournfully when you noticed the scolipede already had several of the innocent Sisters wriggling around in her belly. You may not have any combat experience… but you had to help somehow!

Finding the ninetales would probably be the best place to start. You didn’t see her anywhere along the front lines, so you sprinted towards the back of the monastery, wondering if you might find her hiding there or something. Unfortunately, the darkened, abandoned back corridors turned out to be eerily quiet in comparison to the entrance. “H-hello!? Ninetales?” You call out, your voice echoing unheard down the hallways. You thought you were utterly and completely alone… at least, until another voice split the silence.

“What do we have here?” A deep, powerful voice boomed from behind you. You turned around, only to see the silhouette of a luxray sitting at the other end of the hall, obscured in darkness. “According to my intel, you’re one of Adriana’s friends. Isn’t that right?”

You were deeply startled by his sudden appearance. Was he one of Marden’s goons? Did he sneak in through the back? You were contemplating running, but he didn’t seem hostile at the moment. “Adriana?” You stutter. “Y-you mean the ninetales?”

He stands, walking towards you down the hallway at a leisurely pace. Eventually, he steps out into the light, revealing his sly smile, and the strange black vest wrapped around his shoulders.“Pfft. She hasn’t even told you her name? Figures. If she had, you might read over a wanted poster sometime and see she’s a criminal. A murderer.”

As he approached you, you back away at the same pace. “W-what are you talking about?”

“Your ‘friend’ has digested thirty-nine civilized Pokemon. That’s not even counting the wild ones. She’s one of the most wanted Pokemon in the region.”

“N-no! You’re bullshitting me!” You insist, seeing a crack in his story. “Hell, that scolipede outside -- she’s eating Pokemon right now!”

“She’s imprisoning them for later prosecution,” he rolled his eyes. “They’ll be unharmed, don’t you worry yourself.”

You trusted the luxray about as far as you could throw him. “Where is… ‘Adriana’?” You growled, growing more and more panicked. “What did you do to her?”

“You searched the whole monastery, and she’s nowhere to be found. Hm! Why don’t you put two and two together, kid?” He said, almost mockingly. “She left. She snuck out the back the second this whole raid started. She was just using you, and the second things went south, she left you for dead.” He saw the look of denial on your face. “Don’t believe me? Well, where is she then? Do you have a better explanation?”

You shake your head, almost on the verge of tears. You were so confused. You’d never had to deal with something like this before. It felt like your world was unravelling for the first time since your parents first left.. “No… you’re working for Marden…”

With a grimace, he gestured to the ornate golden badge pinned to his vest, emblazoned with the words Shipton Police. “I don’t know what Adriana’s told you, boy, but Marden’s the chief of police,” he revealed. “You strike me as a good kid, though. Just got mixed up in the wrong crowd. If you agree to come peacefully, I’ll bring you back to the station and we can clear this whole thing up. You tell us what you know, we’ll pretend you never aided a wanted criminal.” He opened his maw, giving you a good look of his deep, dark throat, giving you an idea of exactly what it was he was asking you to do. “What do you say?” He was so close, you couldn’t afford to keep this conversation going any longer. Besides… if the ninetales did just abandon you here, hearing the luxray out may be your best chance...
